verses.text: In the month of Nisan, in the twentieth year of King Artaxerxes, when wine was set before him, I took the wine and gave it to the king. Now I had never been sad in his presence before.
verses.comment: Marks a distinct time. The month of Nisan aligns with the start of Passover (Ex. 12:2), hinting at redemption themes.

verses.text: And the king said to me, 'Why is your face sad, since you are not sick? This can be nothing but sadness of heart.' Then I was very much afraid.
verses.comment: The king's insight underlines the importance of discernment. Nehemiah’s fear reflects the risk involved when approaching royal authority—echoing Esther’s risk before the king (Esth. 4:11-16).

verses.text: I said to the king, 'Let the king live forever! Why should my face not be sad, when the city where my ancestors are buried lies in ruins, and its gates have been destroyed by fire?'
verses.comment: Nehemiah appeals to reverence for ancestors, a theme seen throughout Scripture, reflecting continuity and tradition. Reference to the destroyed gates recalls the exile’s impact.

verses.text: Then the king said to me, 'What are you requesting?' So I prayed to the God of heaven.
verses.comment: Nehemiah’s quick prayer shows reliance on divine guidance in crucial moments—a model of continual prayer (1 Thess. 5:17).

verses.text: And I said to the king, 'If it pleases the king, and if your servant has found favor before you, send me to Judah, to the city of my ancestors’ tombs, so that I may rebuild it.'
verses.comment: Favor before the king is seen as providential. The idea of rebuilding echoes God’s work of restoration—foreshadowed in Christ’s promise to rebuild His temple (Jn. 2:19-21).

verses.text: And the king said to me—with the queen sitting beside him—'How long will your journey take, and when will you return?' So it pleased the king to send me, and I gave him a time.
verses.comment: The presence of the queen may hint at her influence. Timing in restoration is crucial—God’s plans unfold according to divine schedule (Eccl. 3:1).

verses.text: And I said to the king, 'If it pleases the king, may letters be given to me for the governors of the region beyond the River, so that they may permit me to pass through until I come to Judah;
verses.comment: Nehemiah’s request for letters shows the importance of both spiritual authority and legitimate earthly approval. This foreshadows the need for established leadership and order in God’s community.

verses.text: and a letter to Asaph, the keeper of the king’s forest, that he may give me timber to make beams for the gates of the fortress adjoining the temple, and for the city wall, and for the house I will occupy.’ And the king granted me what I asked, because the gracious hand of my God was upon me.
verses.comment: Provision for God’s house and the city wall shows the importance of material resources in supporting spiritual purposes.

verses.text: Then I came to the governors of the region beyond the River and gave them the king’s letters. Now the king had sent with me officers of the army and horsemen.
verses.comment: The accompanying royal escort shows the importance of divine protection and the legitimacy of Nehemiah’s mission, paralleling biblical leadership with authority and support.

verses.text: But when Sanballat the Horonite and Tobiah the Ammonite official heard, it was very displeasing to them that someone had come to seek the well-being of the Israelites.
verses.comment: Opposition to God’s people is a recurring theme. The restoration of Jerusalem foreshadows ultimate spiritual restoration in Christ.

verses.text: So I arrived in Jerusalem, and after being there three days,
verses.comment: ‘Three days’ often signifies completion or readiness in scripture (Gen. 22:4; Hos. 6:2; Matt. 12:40), prefiguring resurrection motifs.

verses.text: I arose in the night, I and a few men with me, and I told no one what my God had put in my heart to do for Jerusalem. There was no animal with me except the one upon which I rode.
verses.comment: Acting in secrecy prepares for God's work, akin to prophecy of the coming King (Zech. 9:9; Matt. 21), who enters Jerusalem humbly.

verses.text: I went out by night through the Valley Gate toward the Dragon’s Well and to the Dung Gate, inspecting the walls of Jerusalem that were broken down and its gates destroyed by fire.
verses.comment: Inspection acts as preparation for restoration. Nighttime often signifies spiritual struggle and transition to light.

verses.text: Then I passed on to the Fountain Gate and to the King’s Pool, but there was no room for my animal to pass.
verses.comment: The King’s Pool recalls sources of spiritual life (see Ps. 36:9: ‘For with you is the fountain of life’), pointing toward cleansing and renewal.

verses.text: So I went up by night through the valley and inspected the wall. Then I turned back and entered through the Valley Gate, and so returned.
verses.comment: The thorough inspection reflects careful discernment, needed for any spiritual renewal. Returning through the same gate symbolizes coming full circle in restoration.

verses.text: The officials did not know where I had gone or what I was doing, and I had not yet told the Jews, the priests, the nobles, the officials, or the rest who would work on the task.
verses.comment: Secrecy before public revelation recalls how Jesus sometimes instructed His disciples not to publicize His mission prematurely.

verses.text: Then I said to them, 'You see the trouble we are in—how Jerusalem lies in ruins and its gates are burned. Come, let us rebuild the wall of Jerusalem, that we may no longer be a disgrace.'
verses.comment: Corporate responsibility and action for restoration reflect God’s call to community. Spiritual renewal is a communal endeavor.

verses.text: And I told them how the gracious hand of my God had been upon me, and also the words the king had spoken to me. And they said, 'Let us rise up and build.' So they strengthened their hands for this good work.
verses.comment: God’s grace working through authority encourages unity and action in God’s people. All must ‘rise up and build’ together, as in the one spiritual house (1 Pet. 2:5).

verses.text: But when Sanballat the Horonite, Tobiah the Ammonite official, and Geshem the Arab heard, they mocked and despised us, saying, 'What is this thing you are doing? Are you rebelling against the king?'
verses.comment: Opposition and ridicule echo persecution of the righteous. Just as Jesus faced mockery, God’s servants endure suffering for restoring His people.

verses.text: Then I replied to them, 'The God of heaven will make us prosper, and we, His servants, will arise and build. But you have no share or right or memorial in Jerusalem.'
verses.comment: Assurance comes from belonging to God’s people, having a share in God’s city. Only those joined to His covenant participate in the fullness of restoration.
